text: Google seems to have different rules for big publishers like Pinterest in the New York Times where they rank things that are gated, but for the rest of us, if it’s a gated, it’s probably not getting ranked or given any authority by Google

text: Hello! Not all of our members are guys. In an effort to be more conscious of the language we use to address each other, why not try “Hey, folks,” or “Hey everyone” instead?

Hi all! Long post to follow about measuring the *business impact* of content. Would love to hear how you all address this in your orgs.

My team is talking content reporting/metrics and I'd love to get some input -- measurement and reporting are definitely not my strong suit. As far as I can tell, measurements fall into two different buckets:
1. *How "hook-y" is the content?* - Is it bringing in new leads/bringing new people to our website?
2. *Is the content high-quality?* - Is it of interest to our audience, and is it helping move them down the sales funnel?

The first lends itself to more classic content metrics (downloads, MoM organic blog traffic growth, etc), but the second is trickier. We can measure things like webinar audience attendance rate to see if people are engaging with the content, but that doesn't help make the leap to whether we're engaging with our target audience. I'm thinking we need to be measuring something like Pipeline Influenced or Opportunities Influenced, but the feedback is that those metrics belong to other depts. (Opportunities Influenced, for example, would be owned by Sales Enablement, which coaches the sales team on how to use the content created by my team.)

We're currently kicking around *Inquiry -> AQL conversion rate* (which theoretically is measuring the success of our lead warming email campaigns, which use content to increase people's lead score to the point we believe they're ready to be contacted by sales). I don't think this fully captures the impact of our content.

Any thoughts on the best way to measure the *business impact* of content? I realize this is a perennial struggle for content marketers, so I'd also love to have a conversation with anyone who has strong opinions on this!

Is the content high-quality?

- Is it of interest to our audience, and is it helping move them down the sales funnel?

The first lends itself to more classic content metrics (downloads, MoM organic blog traffic growth, etc), but the second is trickier. We can measure things like webinar audience attendance rate to see if people are engaging with the content, but that doesn't help make the leap to whether we're engaging with our target audience. I'm thinking we need to be measuring something like Pipeline Influenced or Opportunities Influenced, but the feedback is that those metrics belong to other depts. (Opportunities Influenced, for example, would be owned by Sales Enablement, which coaches the sales team on how to use the content created by my team.)

We're currently kicking around
Inquiry -> AQL conversion rate

(which theoretically is measuring the success of our lead warming email campaigns, which use content to increase people's lead score to the point we believe they're ready to be contacted by sales). I don't think this fully captures the impact of our content.

Any thoughts on the best way to measure the
business impact
of content? I realize this is a perennial struggle for content marketers, so I'd also love to have a conversation with anyone who has strong opinions on this!

text:
Mmm yeah the subjective measures are pretty tricky to translate into the quantitative realm.

Re: interest: My gut says to rely on the SEO metrics. SEO performance is a signal about usefulness in the wider world. See if other entities in your space are linking to you, etc.

Re: moving down the sales funnel: I don't know any good way to do this other than some complex attribution analysis. You have to have a pretty robust tracking system in place to get a good sense of how content engagement relates to the customer journey. it gets murky fast, and the nuances of "ensuring accuracy" quickly leave the realm of "high level" stats. Sounds like the silos you've mentioned might prevent even starting down this path anyway

An informal approach might be legit more cost effective. Get salespeople to ask if prospects/clients are reading the [content]. Collect qualitative feedback to support the quant stuff from the hooky measurement.

Another idea: ping either strong prospects or new clients with a simple NPS style survey: "did our [content] help you make your decision to reach out?" etc. This is something of a compromise between hard quant stuff and squishy qual

text:
For conversion metrics:
• Demo referrals from blog as first page seen (tracked in GA via custom report)
• MQLs generated from blog as first page seen (tracked in GA or hubspot)
• Opps generated from blog as first page seen (Hubspot)
• Customers generated from blog as first page seen (also hubspot)
For our traffic metrics, I mostly use GA custom reports and SEMRush.
The conversion metrics have helped me identify posts that generate lots of clicks to our demo page, and even some demo requests, but ultimately no opps or leads, meaning the content speaks to our anti-personas (interested in our product but ultimately unqualified due to size/budget/etc.) better than our target personas and needs to be edited. However this is definitely a work in progress and i'm excited to hear how others do it. :slightly_smiling_face: FYI this is too manual to track all of them weekly, I've aimed for monthly. Weekly I only track demo referrals and MQLs.

elements.text: For conversion metrics:
Demo referrals from blog as first page seen (tracked in GA via custom report)
MQLs generated from blog as first page seen (tracked in GA or hubspot)
Opps generated from blog as first page seen (Hubspot)
Customers generated from blog as first page seen (also hubspot)

For our traffic metrics, I mostly use GA custom reports and SEMRush.
The conversion metrics have helped me identify posts that generate lots of clicks to our demo page, and even some demo requests, but ultimately no opps or leads, meaning the content speaks to our anti-personas (interested in our product but ultimately unqualified due to size/budget/etc.) better than our target personas and needs to be edited. However this is definitely a work in progress and i'm excited to hear how others do it.
FYI this is too manual to track all of them weekly, I've aimed for monthly. Weekly I only track demo referrals and MQLs.

text: <@U031FGLGPC5> -- do you feel like those metrics rely heavily on demand gen? MQLs generated from an ebook, for example, are going to be heavily dependent on how successful our ads + partnerships are at publicizing the ebook. Blog metrics are less so, they're more likely to be influenced by SEO (unless you're promoting your blog posts successfully through another avenue?), but I'm hesitant to base too many metrics around SEO (cc: <@U01AHL8AGBB>) -- one of our main personas gets to us via search, but the other one (C-suite execs) does not, and we create content for both.

text:
You’ve asked about *business impact* of content…so I’d recommend the following breakdown/way to think about metrics: content is usually either a) growing your brand awareness or
b) helping people buy or learn about your solutions/services.

*Brand awareness metrics* fall under traffic, social shares, SEO rankings and CTR, newsletter subscribers/new followers, generic content downloads, etc. Not everyone is ready to buy today--but you need them to know you and be familiar with you when they are. This is important if you have high growth goals (plans to double, triple growth) and have long sales cycles. The benefit to the business isn’t always tangible to immediates sales--but it’s important work to do. If you never focus on TOFU or brand plays that get you noticed, and only focus on BOFU/lead gen, you will likely not be able to scale, long-term.
*Helping people buy*: This is stuff like demo requests, conversions (MQLs, SAOs, etc), engagement later in the funnel, pipeline influenced/closed, etc. etc. This needs to be tracked to justify budgets to the bean counters and those who don’t get marketing--and make sure your BOFU/MOFU content is actually doing its job.
…I do, however, think a third pool of metrics to consider looking at that also exists is *content quality*: this is time spent on page/ebooks, downloads, feedback/positive comments, link backs/shout outs/press coverage or pick up, etc. This tells you if your content is truly good or not, impacting the profession or field, etc. because it signals people thought it was good enough to really engage with it and even advocate for it. You could lump this in under ‘brand metrics,’ but I think your contnet/comms team will care more about these as indicators of the right content quality/format/topics/messaging more  than someone higher up or on an outside team who wants to see the “business impact” of your content.

p.s. I can’t believe you said you’re not strong at data stuff and yet you just listed/shared a ton of thoughtful stuff to track in your original post. Give yourself credit--you are on the right path, doing the right thinking, and asking good questions.

You could lump this in under ‘brand metrics,’ but I think your contnet/comms team will care more about these as indicators of the right content quality/format/topics/messaging more  than someone higher up or on an outside team who wants to see the “business impact” of your content.

text:
I prefer to focus on marketing sourced pipeline over marketing influenced. Unless there’s a tight firm cutoff point on how far back “influenced” can be. Otherwise we end up being marketers justifying our existing because some opportunity downloaded our ebook or a year ago (that they don't even remember). :upside_down_face:

Over time we realized that rather than try to fumble around with attribution to tie it to ROI, the time was better spent finding other content formats and distribution channels that made it more apparent and clear.

Things as simple as asking customers how they heard about us shed a lot of light on things and woke us up to reality.

Things as simple as asking customers how they heard about us shed a lot of light on things and woke us up to reality.

text:
I strongly believe that content reporting needs to tie back to revenue metrics -- regardless of whether you're dependent on other teams (demand gen, sales, etc) to drive those results (MQLs, demos, pipeline).

The way I think about it is, we're all on the same team. Content certainly has more control over some metrics than others (ex: we can more directly influence new MQLs from content vs. the sales team opening an inbound opp from a content-sourced lead). But we're _still_ accountable b/c it's also part of our job to partner with demand gen and sales to effectively use our content. And -- bigger picture -- if we're doing our job well, our content _should_ be impacting the entire funnel, from first-touch on our blog to an opened opportunity.

Plus, as you know, these are the metrics that marketing leadership and company leadership care about :slightly_smiling_face:

Here's what my team's content scorecard tracks from quarter to quarter. It's not perfect -- but it keeps things simple, ladders up to our Marketing goals, and gives us solid direction:

• Total blog traffic
• Organic blog traffic
• New MQLs from content gates
    ◦ New MQLs from organic search
• Demos with content gate as lead source
• New inbound pipeline opened w/ content gate as lead source
We also produce monthly Content Reports with much more detailed performance metrics on individual content pieces and campaigns.
